questions.text: Ebola virus comes under which Biosafety level category as given by WHO? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 4.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Ebola virus is classified under Biosafety Level 4 (BSL-4) by WHO, indicating it is one of the most dangerous pathogens requiring the highest level of containment.

questions.text: A patient with a history of TB presents with hemoptysis. X-ray is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aspergilloma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspergilloma is a fungal infection that commonly occurs in pre-existing lung cavities from conditions such as tuberculosis. It presents as a cavity with a fungal ball inside and can cause hemoptysis, which may be severe.

questions.text: Vomiting in pregnancy is managed by? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Small frequent meals

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Managing vomiting in pregnancy is best achieved by advising small, frequent meals to help stabilize blood sugar levels and reduce nausea.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to your clinic for a routine physical examination. You decide to assess his carotid artery pulse. At what level of the neck should you palpate to feel the common carotid artery pulse? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cricoid cartilage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The common carotid artery pulse is palpated at the level of the cricoid cartilage, lateral to the trachea, and adjacent to the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

questions.text: A patient presented with strong upper limb pulses and weak lower limb pulses with chest x-ray showing rib notching. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Coarctation of Aorta

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Coarctation of the aorta is identified by the presence of strong upper limb pulses, weak lower limb pulses, and rib notching on a chest x-ray, which is caused by collateral circulation developing around the narrowed section of the aorta.

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient presented with fever, headache, vomiting, and neck stiffness. Lumbar puncture was performed, and the reports are as follows: (FMGE JULY 2024) Opening pressure – elevated Appearance – cloudy Cell count – 80 (70% PMNs) Sugar – 35 mg/dL Protein – 200 mg/dL What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acute Bacterial Meningitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute bacterial meningitis is characterized by elevated opening pressure, cloudy CSF, a high cell count with neutrophilic predominance, low glucose, and elevated protein levels in the CSF.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a fetal cause of polyhydramnios? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Renal agenesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with complaints of painful urination, joint pain, and redness in both eyes for the past two weeks. He mentions a recent episode of diarrhoea but denies any sexual activity. Physical examination reveals inflammation of the knees and conjunctivitis. Laboratory testing reveals a positive HLA-B27 antigen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Reiter syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Reiter syndrome (reactive arthritis) is associated with HLA-B27 and presents with the triad of urethritis, arthritis, and conjunctivitis. It commonly follows infections, particularly gastrointestinal or genitourinary, and treatment includes addressing the underlying infection and managing inflammation.

questions.text: A patient presents with acute onset of double vision, difficulty walking, and confusion. Given a history of alcohol abuse, what is the most appropriate initial treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intravenous thiamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wernicke's encephalopathy, characterized by the triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and confusion, should be treated immediately with intravenous thiamine to prevent serious neurological damage.

questions.text: A patient after RTA (Road Traffic Accident) presented with hypovolemic shock. What is the reason for decreased cardiac output in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Decreased preload

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In hypovolemic shock, the primary cause of decreased cardiac output is decreased preload due to significant loss of blood volume.

questions.text: A patient experiences chest pain radiating to the arm. Which nerve can be responsible for the radiating pain? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intercostobrachial nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The intercostobrachial nerve, originating from T2, is responsible for the sensation in the upper medial arm and can be involved in referred pain from the chest, such as during a myocardial infarction. This nerve is key in understanding the dermatome distribution related to cardiac pain.

questions.text: An HIV patient presents with breathlessness and cough. His recent CD4 count was less than 200 and the patient’s chest X-ray is shown. BAL was done and reports are pending. What is the likely diagnosis and treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pneumocystis jiroveci; Cotrimoxazole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In an HIV patient with a CD4 count less than 200, presenting with breathlessness and bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray, the likely diagnosis is Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (PJP), and the treatment of choice is cotrimoxazole.

questions.text: A child presents with painful corneal erosions, photophobia, and thickening of the palms and soles (palmoplantar keratosis). Laboratory investigations reveal a defect in tyrosine metabolism. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Type 2 Tyrosinemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type 2 Tyrosinemia is characterized by painful corneal erosions , photophobia , and palmoplantar keratosis , resulting from a deficiency in Tyrosine transaminase .
  • ➤ painful corneal erosions
  • ➤ photophobia
  • ➤ palmoplantar keratosis
  • ➤ Tyrosine transaminase

questions.text: A child presented with dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cretinism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cretinism, or congenital hypothyroidism, should be considered in infants presenting with dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia. Early diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent long-term developmental delays.

questions.text: What is Gaisböck syndrome? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Relative polycythemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gaisböck syndrome is a form of relative polycythemia caused by a reduction in plasma volume, often due to dehydration, leading to an apparent increase in red blood cell concentration.

questions.text: During excision of ranula along with sublingual gland, which structure is most likely to be injured? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lingual nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During the excision of a ranula and the sublingual gland, the lingual nerve is the structure most likely to be injured due to its anatomical position relative to the sublingual gland. This nerve is responsible for sensory innervation of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and its injury can result in significant sensory deficits.

questions.text: A 27-year-old lady presented to OPD with a complaint of pain and redness in her breast with fever. On clinical examination, a 5 x 4 cm area of redness was noted in the breast with ipsilateral axillary lymph node enlargement. What should be the preferred management in this lady? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Antibiotics and breast support

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary treatment for mastitis includes antibiotics to address the infection and breast support to alleviate discomfort. Recognize the symptoms of mastitis and differentiate it from a breast abscess, which requires a different management approach.

questions.text: A researcher is analyzing an RNA sample with the sequence CAAGGU. Based on this RNA sequence, what would be the corresponding template sequence in the original DNA strand from which the RNA was transcribed? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) ACCTTG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During transcription, the RNA sequence is complementary to the DNA template. In RNA, adenine pairs with uracil, while cytosine pairs with guanine. The transcription process creates an RNA strand that is the reverse complement of the DNA template strand.

questions.text: In a standard normal distribution, what percentage of data values fall within one standard deviation of the mean? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 68%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a standard normal distribution, 68% of the data values fall within one standard deviation of the mean.

questions.text: For newborn hearing screening purpose, which test is most commonly used? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) OAE

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE) testing is the standard and most commonly used initial screening method for detecting hearing loss in newborns due to its simplicity, quick results, and effectiveness.

questions.text: A patient had a history of TIA and was admitted. 48 hours later he developed severe respiratory difficulty and fever. What is the probable cause? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hospital Acquired Pneumonia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pneumonia developing 48 hours or more after hospital admission is classified as hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP).

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after showing symptoms of a stroke. He is able to understand questions and follow commands but struggles to speak or form words properly. He makes sounds and gestures as if trying to speak, but his words lack fluency. Based on this clinical presentation, which type of aphasia is most likely? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Broca's aphasia is characterized by difficulty in speech production while comprehension remains intact. It is caused by damage to Broca's area in the left frontal lobe, often due to a stroke. Patients are aware of their speech difficulties, which differentiates it from Wernicke's aphasia where comprehension is impaired.
  • ➤ Broca's aphasia

questions.text: Most common cause of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Gestational thrombocytopenia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gestational thrombocytopenia is the most common cause of mild thrombocytopenia during pregnancy and is usually not associated with adverse outcomes.

questions.text: 18-year-old girl presents with bilateral ptosis and difficulty in chewing and combing. Her problems tend to worsen with activity. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Myasthenia Gravis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myasthenia Gravis is characterized by muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest, with ptosis and difficulty in tasks requiring sustained muscle effort being common symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following hormone increases during periods of stress, starvation, and deep sleep? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) GH (Growth Hormone)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Growth Hormone (GH) increases during periods of stress, starvation, and deep sleep, especially during the NREM stage 3 of sleep.

questions.text: All of the following are initial management options of CSF rhinorrhea except: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The initial management of CSF rhinorrhea includes conservative measures such as bed rest, use of acetazolamide, and antibiotics to prevent infection. Diagnostic imaging like HRCT can help identify the defect. Steroids followed by FESS is not appropriate for the initial management of CSF rhinorrhea as it is unrelated to addressing the CSF leak.

questions.text: A patient complained of ear discharge, retro-orbital pain, and visual disturbances. What is the diagnosis: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Petrositis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gradenigo's syndrome (Petrositis) presents with the triad of ear discharge, retro-orbital pain, and sixth nerve palsy causing visual disturbances. This is due to the spread of chronic ear infection to the petrous apex of the temporal bone, affecting adjacent cranial nerves.

questions.text: A woman who got IUCD inserted at a PHC, now presents with bleeding. What should be done by the MO? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Iron supplement and observation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Iron supplementation and observation are crucial in managing post-IUCD insertion bleeding to prevent anemia. If bleeding persists, further action, such as removing the IUCD, may be necessary.
  • ➤ Iron supplementation and observation

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman complains of ptosis and diplopia that worsens with activity and improves with rest. What is the most sensitive investigation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) EMG (Electromyography)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most sensitive investigation for diagnosing myasthenia gravis is electromyography (EMG), particularly single fiber EMG, which detects abnormalities in neuromuscular transmission.

questions.text: Acute sudden painful diminution of vision with vertically oval pupil is caused by: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Angle closure glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute angle closure glaucoma is characterized by sudden, painful vision loss, and a mid-dilated, vertically oval, sluggishly reacting pupil. Recognizing these signs is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment to prevent permanent vision loss.

questions.text: What blood group should be given to a patient with Bombay blood group? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Bombay blood group (Oh phenotype) is extremely rare, and individuals with this blood type can only receive blood from another Bombay blood group donor due to the absence of the H antigen and the presence of anti-H antibodies.

questions.text: A person who at the time of commission of the offense was of unsound mind, is exempt if he didn't know the nature of the act or its consequences. This rule is known as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) McNaughton rule

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In India, the McNaughton rule is used to determine criminal responsibility for individuals with mental illness. According to this rule, a person is exempt from criminal responsibility if they were unable to understand the nature of their act or know that it was wrong due to their mental condition.

questions.text: A study was done in 3 districts to measure the mean blood pressure. Health workers visited each house of the 3 districts. Identify the epidemiological study design. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cross sectional study.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A cross-sectional study collects data from a population at one point in time, often used to determine the prevalence of a condition like hypertension.

questions.text: The Honorable Supreme Court of India has banned one of the following, which is infamous among doctors for sexual assault cases: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Two finger test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The two-finger test, previously used to assess whether a woman was "habituated to sex," has been banned by the Supreme Court of India due to its irrelevance, discriminatory nature, and potential to cause additional trauma to sexual assault victims.

questions.text: Which of the following is the pattern of inheritance with the pedigree chart provided in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mitochondrial inheritance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mitochondrial inheritance is characterized by the transmission of a trait from an affected mother to all of her offspring, while affected males do not pass the trait to their children. This unique pattern is due to the inheritance of mitochondrial DNA, which is maternally inherited.
  • ➤ Example of Maternal/ mitochondrial inheritance diseases: Leber's Optic Neuropathy , MELAS Syndrome (Mitochondrial Encephalopathy, Lactic Acidosis, and Stroke-like manifestation).
  • ➤ Leber's Optic Neuropathy

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with fatigue and tiredness. He had low Hb and reticulocyte count. BM reveals a decrease in erythroid precursors. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pure red cell aplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pure red cell aplasia is characterized by a specific decrease in erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, leading to anemia with normal WBC and platelet counts.

questions.text: A child was brought to ENT OPD with complaints of mouth breathing and snoring from a long duration. He also asks to increase the volume of TV while watching. What is the best treatment for this child’s condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Adenoidectomy and grommet

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of chronic adenoid hypertrophy causing mouth breathing, snoring, and conductive hearing loss, the best treatment involves adenoidectomy along with the insertion of a grommet to ensure proper drainage of middle ear fluid and restore normal hearing.

questions.text: Banana sign and lemon sign are seen in? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) NTD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Banana sign and lemon sign are ultrasound findings seen in neural tube defects (NTD), particularly in cases of spina bifida.

questions.text: A vegetable vendor with no criminal background, after 1 week is found dead with advanced decomposition. What would you do to recognize the body? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) DNA profiling

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of advanced decomposition, DNA profiling is the most reliable method for identifying a body, as it can still be obtained from bones and other tissues even after significant decomposition.

questions.text: Local anesthesia used in cataract surgery is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lignocaine 2%

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lignocaine 2% is the standard local anesthetic used in cataract surgery due to its rapid onset and appropriate duration of action. However, it's important to note that topical anesthesia using proparacaine 0.5% is becoming increasingly common in modern cataract surgery techniques.

questions.text: Marker for ectopic pregnancy is? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Beta hCG

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Beta hCG is the primary marker used to diagnose and manage ectopic pregnancies, providing essential information about pregnancy location and viability.

questions.text: During endoscopy, the endoscope has reached 25 cm from the incisor teeth. The endoscope has reached till: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 58-year-old hypertensive patient with a history of myocardial infarction (MI) presents with an acute attack of migraine. Which of the following medications should not be given? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sumatriptan

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sumatriptan, a vasoconstrictor, should not be given to patients with a history of coronary artery disease or myocardial infarction due to the risk of triggering serious cardiovascular events.

questions.text: Multiple Lisch nodules are a feature of which of the following conditions? (FMGE JULY 2024)

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with chest pain and an ECG was taken. What will be the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with dyslipidemia has persistently elevated triglyceride levels (600 mg/dL) despite treatment with rosuvastatin. What will be the next step? (FMGE JULY 2024)

questions.text: A patient presented with fever for 5 days and you are suspecting enteric fever. What is the best way to diagnose? (FMGE JULY 2024)

  • • Key points:
  • • Blood cultures: The best diagnostic method for enteric fever during the first week of illness, as the bacteria are present in the blood. Bone marrow cultures: While they have the highest sensitivity at any stage of the disease, they are more invasive and less commonly performed compared to blood cultures.

questions.text: A 28-year-old P1L1 with irregular bleeding for 1.5 months. What is the next best investigation to do? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In a 28-year-old woman with irregular bleeding for 1.5 months, the first step is to rule out pregnancy. The initial investigation in this scenario should be a urine pregnancy test (UPT). This is crucial because pregnancy-related complications such as threatened abortion, incomplete abortion, or ectopic pregnancy can present with irregular bleeding. Identifying or excluding pregnancy is the most immediate concern and guides subsequent management.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. TVS (Transvaginal Ultrasound): This is a valuable tool for assessing pelvic pathology and uterine abnormalities, but it is typically done after confirming the UPT results.
  • • Option B. TVS (Transvaginal Ultrasound):
  • • Option C. Pap smear: This test is used for cervical cancer screening and is not the immediate next step in evaluating irregular bleeding when pregnancy needs to be ruled out first.
  • • Option C. Pap smear:
  • • Option D. USG abdomen: While an abdominal ultrasound can provide useful information, it is less sensitive than a transvaginal ultrasound for early pregnancy detection and pelvic pathology assessment.
  • • Option D. USG abdomen:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a reproductive-age woman with irregular bleeding, the first investigation should be a urine pregnancy test (UPT) to rule out pregnancy-related causes.

questions.text: Which of the following is earliest to rise in myocardial infarction? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ischemia modified albumin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the event of a myocardial infarction, certain biomarkers are released into the bloodstream as a result of cardiac muscle injury.
  • • Among the three early markers of myocardial injury , three are particularly significant: myoglobin, heart-type fatty acid binding protein (HFABP), and ischemia modified albumin (IMA). Of these three, ischemia modified albumin is the earliest to rise and also the earliest to fall in response to myocardial ischemia. This rapid change makes it a valuable early diagnostic marker for detecting myocardial infarction.
  • • three early markers of myocardial injury
  • • myoglobin, heart-type fatty acid binding protein (HFABP), and ischemia modified albumin (IMA).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Troponin: Troponins are highly specific markers for myocardial injury and are considered the gold standard for diagnosing myocardial infarction. However, they do not rise as early as ischemia modified albumin. Typically, troponin levels start to rise 4-6 hours after the onset of myocardial infarction.
  • • Option A. Troponin:
  • • Option C. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): LDH is an enzyme found in almost all body tissues and is not specific to cardiac tissue. It is a later marker of myocardial infarction, usually rising within 24-48 hours after the onset of symptoms.
  • • Option C. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase):
  • • Option D. CK MB (Creatine Kinase-MB): CK-MB is a specific isoenzyme found in heart muscle and is used as a marker for myocardial infarction. However, it does not rise as early as ischemia modified albumin. CK-MB levels typically start to increase 3-6 hours after myocardial infarction.
  • • Option D. CK MB (Creatine Kinase-MB):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ischemia modified albumin is the earliest biomarker to rise in the event of a myocardial infarction, making it a crucial early indicator for diagnosis.

questions.text: The 1 st sign to be seen in Mg toxicity in a patient receiving MgSO 4 for eclampsia is? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.correct_answer: C. Loss of DTRs (Deep Tendon Reflexes)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Loss of DTRs (Deep Tendon Reflexes)

Explanation:

  • • Detailed Explanation:
  • • Magnesium Sulfate in Eclampsia : MgSO 4 is used to prevent seizures in patients with eclampsia. While effective, it has a narrow therapeutic range, making monitoring for toxicity essential. Monitoring Signs : Loss of DTRs : This is the earliest sign of magnesium toxicity. Clinicians regularly check for the presence of deep tendon reflexes to ensure they are intact. Respiratory Depression : Following the loss of DTRs, respiratory depression can occur if magnesium levels continue to rise. Cardiac Arrest : In severe cases, unchecked magnesium toxicity can lead to cardiac arrest.

Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Painful scrotal swelling with fever and fluid collection in an adult male, particularly in relation to the tunica vaginalis, suggests a diagnosis of secondary hydrocele due to epididymo-orchitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for balance and equilibrium? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The semicircular canals are critical for detecting angular movements and maintaining balance and equilibrium in conjunction with the vestibule, which detects linear movements and head position relative to gravity.

questions.text: A patient presented with a fall on an outstretched hand. On X-ray, a fracture of the base of the 1st metacarpal bone was seen. This type of fracture is also known as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bennett's fracture is an intra-articular fracture at the base of the first metacarpal bone, commonly caused by a fall on an outstretched hand. It is important to recognize this fracture due to its involvement with the CMC joint and potential for dislocation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with pedal edema, abdominal distension, and distended neck veins. Chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following will be seen? (FMGE JULY 2024)

options.label: B
options.text: SBP fall from 80 mm Hg to 60 mm Hg during inspiration

questions.correct_answer: B. SBP fall from 80 mm Hg to 60 mm Hg during inspiration
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) SBP fall from 80 mm Hg to 60 mm Hg during inspiration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cardiac tamponade is characterized by pulsus paradoxus, which is a significant drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration, often exceeding 10 mm Hg

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about a patient who presented in the OPD with a swelling as shown in the image? The swelling is reducible. (FMGE JULY 2024)

options.label: B
options.text: Reduce the swelling and do the observation

options.label: C
options.text: Do a surgical procedure and reduce the swelling with mesh repair

questions.correct_answer: C. Do a surgical procedure and reduce the swelling with mesh repair
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Do a surgical procedure and reduce the swelling with mesh repair

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For reducible hernias, the appropriate treatment is surgical repair with mesh reinforcement to prevent recurrence and avoid complications. Observation alone is not sufficient, and procedures such as incision and drainage are not applicable.

questions.text: Who conducts inquest in police custodial death? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Judicial magistrate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In India, the inquest for a police custodial death is conducted by a judicial magistrate, ensuring an impartial investigation into the circumstances surrounding the death.

questions.text: A young woman wants to take the post-coital pill. Which one should be given? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) LNG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The preferred emergency contraceptive pill is Levonorgestrel (LNG), to be taken as a single dose within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse.

questions.text: The recommended free/residual chlorine level in the water after chlorination of a well is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Minimum Chlorine Levels : Drinking Water : The minimum free residual chlorine level should be 0.5 milligrams per liter (mg/L) or parts per million (ppm). Swimming Pools : A minimum of 1 ppm of chlorine is required after a 1-hour contact period to ensure safety and cleanliness. Killing Cyclopes : To effectively kill cyclopes in water, the chlorine concentration needs to be at least 2 ppm. Chloroscope device is used to measure chlorine levels in water, ensuring to meet the health and safety standards. Orthotolidine Test is utilized for measuring the chlorine content in water, confirming whether the necessary disinfection levels are being maintained. Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water, which helps determine how much bleaching powder should be added to achieve effective disinfection. The main disinfecting agent in chlorine treatments is hypochlorous acid (HOCl), which is effective in neutralizing pathogens and ensuring water safety.
  • ➤ Minimum Chlorine Levels : Drinking Water : The minimum free residual chlorine level should be 0.5 milligrams per liter (mg/L) or parts per million (ppm). Swimming Pools : A minimum of 1 ppm of chlorine is required after a 1-hour contact period to ensure safety and cleanliness. Killing Cyclopes : To effectively kill cyclopes in water, the chlorine concentration needs to be at least 2 ppm.
  • ➤ Minimum Chlorine Levels
  • ➤ Drinking Water : The minimum free residual chlorine level should be 0.5 milligrams per liter (mg/L) or parts per million (ppm). Swimming Pools : A minimum of 1 ppm of chlorine is required after a 1-hour contact period to ensure safety and cleanliness. Killing Cyclopes : To effectively kill cyclopes in water, the chlorine concentration needs to be at least 2 ppm.

  • ➤ Swimming Pools : A minimum of 1 ppm of chlorine is required after a 1-hour contact period to ensure safety and cleanliness.
  • ➤ Swimming Pools
  • ➤ Killing Cyclopes : To effectively kill cyclopes in water, the chlorine concentration needs to be at least 2 ppm.
  • ➤ Killing Cyclopes
  • ➤ Chloroscope device is used to measure chlorine levels in water, ensuring to meet the health and safety standards.
  • ➤ Chloroscope
  • ➤ Orthotolidine Test is utilized for measuring the chlorine content in water, confirming whether the necessary disinfection levels are being maintained.
  • ➤ Orthotolidine Test
  • ➤ Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water, which helps determine how much bleaching powder should be added to achieve effective disinfection.
  • ➤ Horrock’s Apparatus
  • ➤ The main disinfecting agent in chlorine treatments is hypochlorous acid (HOCl), which is effective in neutralizing pathogens and ensuring water safety.

questions.text: Which staging is related to JNA? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Radkowski staging system is specifically used for staging Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA), assessing its extent and guiding treatment options.

questions.text: Identify the type of ulcer. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Trophic ulcer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trophic (neuropathic) ulcers typically occur in weight-bearing areas, such as the soles of the feet, and are surrounded by callosities. They are primarily seen in patients with peripheral neuropathy, where lack of sensation leads to repeated trauma and ulceration. Recognizing this type of ulcer is crucial for appropriate management and prevention of further complications.

questions.text: Innervation of lateral rectus is by which nerve? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) CN VI

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by the sixth cranial nerve (CN VI), also known as the abducens nerve.

questions.text: A patient with bloody diarrhea. Flask-shaped ulcers seen. Infection due to ingestion of quadrinucleate cysts. What is the appropriate treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Metronidazole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient presenting with bloody diarrhea and flask-shaped ulcers caused by Entamoeba histolytica, the appropriate treatment is Metronidazole. This medication is effective against the invasive trophozoite stage of the parasite.

questions.text: What is the neoadjuvant therapy used for GIST? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Imatinib

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Imatinib is the preferred neoadjuvant therapy for GISTs with KIT or certain PDGFRA mutations to reduce tumor size before surgery. It is not effective for all GISTs, particularly those with specific mutations such as PDGFRA D842V or "wild-type" GISTs.

questions.text: Which of the following tissues is most radiosensitive? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Testis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The testis is highly radiosensitive due to the high rate of cell division in germ cells, making it more susceptible to radiation compared to other tissues listed.

questions.text: The heart of the 'Activated sludge process' method is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aeration tank

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The aeration tank is the central component of the Activated Sludge Process, where aerobic bacteria break down organic pollutants in wastewater.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient presents with abdominal pain, joint pain, and palpable purpura. His urine analysis shows RBC casts without any significant findings. The likely diagnosis is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ IgA vasculitis, previously known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura, is characterized by abdominal pain, joint pain, palpable purpura, and renal involvement with RBC casts. It is an IgA-mediated small vessel vasculitis that commonly affects the skin, joints, gastrointestinal tract, and kidneys.

questions.text: Tandem radiotherapy is used in? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cervical cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tandem radiotherapy (intracavitary brachytherapy) is primarily used in the treatment of cervical cancer.

questions.text: Identify what is depicted in the abdominal X-Ray? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The vertical orientation of a stent on an abdominal X-ray is indicative of its placement in the bile duct, particularly in procedures involving ERCP.

questions.text: Benzathine penicillin is given for the treatment of rheumatic fever. This is which level of prevention? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Secondary level

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Secondary prevention involves the treatment of existing conditions, such as rheumatic fever , to prevent further complications.
  • ➤ Secondary prevention
  • ➤ rheumatic fever

questions.text: A young boy came to Derma OPD with complaints of severe itching at night. On examination, burrows are seen over intertriginous areas, axillae, umbilicus, and between digits. The disease is transmitted by? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mite

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Scabies is caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis , which burrows into the skin, causing intense itching, particularly at night, and burrows in characteristic areas such as the axillae, umbilicus, and between the digits.
  • ➤ Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with muscle wasting and skinny appearance. Which of the following condition best fit the diagnosis? ( FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Marasmus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Marasmus is characterized by severe wasting of muscle and subcutaneous fat, leading to a very thin, emaciated appearance in affected children.

questions.text: The formula UV/P represents which one of the following renal functions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Clearance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The formula UV/P is used to calculate the clearance of a substance by the kidneys, which reflects how efficiently the kidneys are filtering the blood.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman with a history of chronic sun exposure presented with bilateral brownish pigmentation over the face as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Melasma, especially in pregnant women, presents as bilateral, symmetrical brownish patches on the face, often linked to sun exposure and hormonal changes.

questions.text: In a cohort study done in a community, out of those 100 vaccinated for malaria, only 6 developed the disease. At the same time, out of those 100 non-vaccinated, a total of 12 developed the disease. Find the relative risk in the study: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 0.5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a cohort study, the relative risk is calculated by comparing the incidence of the outcome in the exposed group to the incidence in the non-exposed group.
  • ➤ A relative risk less than 1 indicates a protective effect of the exposure, as seen in this example where vaccination reduced the risk of malaria.

questions.text: A case of accidental burn injuries in a female patient aged 35 years involving right upper limb, entire right lower limb, entire front and back of abdomen. Which of the following is the percentage of burn injuries according to the rule of nine? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 45%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The total body surface area (TBSA) involved is usually worked out by the Wallace Rule of Nines wherein each upper limb is 9% of TBSA, 9% each for the front and back of lower limb, 9% for the front and back of chest, 9% for the front and back of abdomen, the head and neck 9% and 1% for the perineum.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with blurring of vision, photophobia, and a sensation of mild discomfort in his right eye. On slit-lamp examination, there are aqueous flares, numerous stellate keratic precipitates, and mild iris atrophy. His left eye appears normal. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Iridocyclitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fuchs' heterochromic iridocyclitis presents with unilateral blurring of vision, aqueous flares, and stellate keratic precipitates . It is a chronic, non-granulomatous anterior uveitis. Long-term monitoring is necessary due to the risk of complications such as glaucoma and cataract formation.
  • ➤ unilateral blurring of vision, aqueous flares, and stellate keratic precipitates

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with eye pain, redness, and a sensation of a foreign body in her left eye. She reports wearing contact lenses regularly and admits to not cleaning them as frequently as recommended. Microscopic examination of a corneal scraping reveals a polygonal cyst, as shown in the image. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acanthamoeba

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acanthamoeba keratitis is a serious corneal infection primarily seen in contact lens users. Diagnosis is made by detecting polygonal or star-shaped cysts in corneal scrapings. Proper lens hygiene is crucial in preventing this vision-threatening condition.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is used for sample collection in a tube for blood alcohol concentration measurement? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sodium fluoride + Potassium dichromate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sodium fluoride and potassium dichromate are the substances used in the tube for blood alcohol concentration measurement. Potassium dichromate reacts with ethanol in the blood sample, facilitating the detection and quantification of alcohol concentration
  • ➤ Sodium fluoride and potassium dichromate are the substances used in the tube for blood alcohol concentration measurement.

questions.text: Calcium binds to which one of the following proteins in smooth muscle contraction? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Calmodulin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In smooth muscle cells, calcium binds to calmodulin to initiate muscle contraction, unlike in skeletal muscle where calcium binds to troponin.

questions.text: Which physiological response is most likely to occur in a person exposed to high temperature while exercising vigorously to maintain internal body temperature? (FMGE JULY 2024)

options.label: C
options.text: Increased production of heat by liver

questions.correct_answer: A. Sweating and vasodilation in skin
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sweating and vasodilation in skin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During vigorous exercise in high temperatures, the body primarily responds by increasing sweating and vasodilation to dissipate heat and maintain a stable internal body temperature

questions.text: Which of the following is a tumor marker of carcinoid tumor? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clinically, patients with carcinoid syndrome may present with a range of symptoms including hepatomegaly, bronchospasm that mimics asthma, episodes of vasoconstriction affecting blood vessels, increased intestinal motility manifesting as diarrhea, and distinctive flushing of the skin. The co-occurrence of symptoms like diarrhea, asthma-like respiratory issues, and hepatomegaly should immediately suggest the possibility of carcinoid syndrome.
  • ➤ An increase in the levels of 5-HIAA in blood and urine is a significant indicator (primary tumor marker) of carcinoid syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in a patient with fever and lymph node enlargement whose tissue biopsy image is provided here? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Langhans giant cells, with their horseshoe-shaped nuclei, are a characteristic finding in granulomas associated with tuberculosis, making this the most likely diagnosis in a patient with fever and lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: What concentration of fluoride is typically associated with causing crippling fluorosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ‘Fluorine is a double edged sword’: Inadequate intake is associated with ‘dental caries’ whereas excess intake with ‘dental and skeletal fluorosis’
  • ➤ Crippling fluorosis occurs when fluoride levels in drinking water exceed 10 mg/L, leading to severe and disabling conditions.

questions.text: Presence of different refractive powers (+5D in one eye and +1D in the other eye) in a 10-year-old boy is suggestive of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anisometropic amblyopia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A difference in refractive power between the two eyes of more than 2.5 diopters can lead to anisometropic amblyopia, especially if untreated during the critical period of visual development (up to about 7 years of age)

questions.text: The corrected refractory error is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Presbyopia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Presbyopia is unique among refractive conditions as its correction (typically with reading glasses) results in clear near vision without altering distance vision, effectively achieving a "corrected" state for both near and far vision

questions.text: Which of the following primitive reflexes is expected to persist throughout life? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Parachute reflex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The parachute reflex is a protective reflex that persists throughout life, developing around 7–8 months of age. In contrast, reflexes like the palmar grasp, Moro, and rooting reflexes are typically present at birth and disappear within the first few months of life.
  • ➤ parachute reflex

questions.text: How muscle spindle able to detect the length while muscle is contracting? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Nuclear bag fibers

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nuclear bag fibers in the muscle spindle are responsible for detecting the rate of change in muscle length during muscle contraction, making them essential for proprioception and motor control.

questions.text: Which contrast is used in PET scan? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) FDG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The contrast agent used in PET scans is 18F-FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose) , which highlights areas of increased glucose metabolism, such as cancer cells.
  • ➤ 18F-FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose)

questions.text: A surgical procedure is performed on the great saphenous vein located 2.5 cm anterior to the medial malleolus. Which nerve should be prevented from damage during the ligature? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The saphenous nerve accompanies the great saphenous vein near the medial malleolus and is at risk of injury during surgical procedures in this region.

questions.text: Oil drop cataract is seen in which condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oil drop cataracts are a hallmark feature of galactosemia, an inherited disorder affecting galactose metabolism, and they can present as congenital or developmental cataracts in pediatric patients.

questions.text: Identify the structure being palpated in the image: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Posterior tibial artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior tibial artery can be palpated just behind the medial malleolus, and this is a key location for assessing the arterial blood supply to the foot.

questions.text: A district in Madhya Pradesh has CBR 19/1000 LB and CDR is 6/1000 LB. Find the annual growth rate of the district. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The annual growth rate of a population is calculated by subtracting the Crude Death Rate (CDR) from the Crude Birth Rate (CBR) and then expressing this difference as a percentage.

questions.text: A 5-day-old infant presents with abdominal distension and repeated vomiting. The parents report that the baby has not passed meconium, and he appears uncomfortable during feeding, often regurgitating milk. Physical examination reveals a significantly distended abdomen, and an abdominal X-ray shows a dilated colon. A rectal suction biopsy reveals hypertrophied nerve bundles with an absence of ganglion cells. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hirschsprung's disease is a congenital cause of bowel obstruction due to the absence of ganglion cells in the distal colon. It presents with failure to pass meconium in neonates and abdominal distension. Diagnosis is confirmed through a rectal biopsy showing aganglionosis, and surgical treatment is necessary to relieve the obstruction.

questions.text: An elderly woman with a history of hospitalization for leg cellulitis was prescribed clindamycin. Two days after discharge, she developed severe watery diarrhoea, abdominal pain, fever (38.8°C), and leukocytosis (WBC count 18,000/mm³). Stool tests are pending. What is the most probable causative organism responsible for this presentation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Clostridium difficile

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clostridium difficile is the leading cause of antibiotic-associated diarrhea, particularly following the use of clindamycin, cephalosporins, and fluoroquinolones. Testing involves detecting toxins in the stool, and treatment typically includes oral vancomycin or fidaxomicin .
  • ➤ Clostridium difficile is the leading cause of antibiotic-associated diarrhea, particularly following the use of clindamycin, cephalosporins, and fluoroquinolones.
  • ➤ Clostridium difficile
  • ➤ Testing involves detecting toxins in the stool, and treatment typically includes oral vancomycin or fidaxomicin .
  • ➤ oral vancomycin
  • ➤ fidaxomicin

questions.text: 14-year-old boy with recurrent profuse epistaxis and reddish mass in the nasal cavity: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) JNA (Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) should be suspected in adolescent males who present with recurrent, profuse epistaxis and a reddish mass in the nasal cavity. This condition is characteristic of this age and gender group and requires specific clinical suspicion for accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A patient presented to OPD with dilated tortuous veins in the leg. He had a history of trauma 10 years back in the same limb. On examination, the dilated tortuous vein showed pulsatility. Most likely diagnosis in this patient will be? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) AV fistula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A history of trauma with the presence of dilated tortuous veins showing pulsatility strongly indicates an arteriovenous fistula due to the transmission of arterial pulsation to the veins

questions.text: A 60-year-old female, on treatment for diabetes for the last 10 years, has experienced three episodes of candidal vulvovaginitis in the last two months. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Canagliflozin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with a history of recurrent candidal infections, SGLT2 inhibitors, such as canagliflozin, should be avoided due to their association with increased risk of genital fungal infections.

questions.text: A patient following a road traffic accident presented with subcutaneous emphysema, respiratory distress, and hypotension. On auscultation, there was no air entry on the right side and a hyper-resonant note was felt on percussion. X-ray is shown. What will be your immediate management? (FMGE JULY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Needle thoracostomy in the 5th intercostal space

questions.correct_answer: A. Needle thoracostomy in the 5th intercostal space
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Needle thoracostomy in the 5th intercostal space

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The immediate management for tension pneumothorax is needle thoracostomy in the 5th intercostal space in the mid-axillary line, followed by the insertion of a chest drain.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient undergoing treatment for tuberculosis reports experiencing a decrease in visual acuity and color blindness. Which of the following antitubercular drugs is most likely to cause visual problems? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ethambutol is an antitubercular drug that can cause optic neuritis, leading to a decrease in visual acuity and red-green color blindness.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with complaints of abdominal pain. Further workup showed elevated PTH levels and renal calculi. Which investigation should be done next? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tc-99m sestamibi scan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient with elevated PTH levels and clinical features suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism, such as renal calculi, the Tc-99m sestamibi scan is the preferred investigation to localize a parathyroid adenoma.

questions.text: During delivery of a 30y G2P1L1 with previous LSCS, the head was delivered but the shoulders got stuck. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Shoulder dystocia is diagnosed when the shoulders fail to deliver within a minute after the head or require specific maneuvers for delivery.

questions.text: Gastric lavage is contraindicated in which of the following? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Strychnine poisoning

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gastric lavage is contraindicated in cases of strychnine poisoning due to the high risk of inducing further convulsions and seizures, which can exacerbate the patient's condition.

questions.text: When should early cord clamping be done? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Non vigorous baby

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Early cord clamping is indicated for non-vigorous babies who require immediate resuscitation efforts.

questions.text: What is the typical Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) value in a healthy adult? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 125 ml/min

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The typical Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) value in a healthy adult is approximately 125 ml/min, reflecting normal kidney function.

questions.text: Curtain falling sign is indicative of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Retinal detachment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 3 types of RD: Rhegmatogenous, Tractional and Exudative Retinal Detachment
  • ➤ 3 types of RD:
  • ➤ 1. Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment :
  • ➤ Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment
  • ➤ Most common form, occurring when a tear or hole in the retina allows fluid to enter and accumulate under the retina, separating it from the underlying tissues. Classical symptoms include visual flashes and floaters, which are due to the movement of the detached retina. A "curtain falling" sign, where a section of the visual field appears to be shaded, is characteristic of this type.

  • • Explanation:
  • • The correct answer is emergency cesarean facility should be there . When considering a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC), it is crucial to ensure that the facility is equipped to handle an emergency cesarean section. This is because the risk of complications, including uterine rupture, can pose significant risks to both the mother and the fetus.
  • • emergency cesarean facility should be there
  • • Emergency cesarean facility : The availability of an emergency cesarean section facility is essential for any patient undergoing TOLAC. This ensures that if complications arise, such as uterine rupture, immediate surgical intervention can be provided to minimize risks.
  • • Emergency cesarean facility
  • • Other Option:
  • • Other Option:
  • • Option A. Risk of uterine rupture is 4-9% : This statement is incorrect for a lower segment cesarean section. The risk of uterine rupture in a TOLAC for a lower segment cesarean section is much lower, around 0.2%. The 4-9% risk applies to upper segment or classical cesarean sections.
  • • Option A. Risk of uterine rupture is 4-9%
  • • Additional Considerations for TOLAC:
  • • Additional Considerations for TOLAC:
  • • Interval between pregnancies : The inter-delivery interval should be more than 18 months to allow adequate healing of the uterine scar. Reason for previous cesarean : Conditions like cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) or other recurrent indications may reduce the likelihood of a successful TOLAC and increase the risk of complications. Monitoring : Continuous fetal monitoring during labor is recommended to detect any signs of fetal distress early.

B6 deficiency also leads to increased synthesis of xanthurenic acid Carcinoid syndrome: can be differentiated with elevated HIAA level with pellagra like symptoms. Hartnup disease can present with pellagra-like symptoms due to defective absorption of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids, leading to high aminoaciduria and niacin deficiency.

  • ➤ Carcinoid syndrome: can be differentiated with elevated HIAA level with pellagra like symptoms.

questions.text: A person fell from the train and injured his both legs a few years back. The amputation was done as shown in the image. What is the most likely reason for doing such an amputation? (FMGE JULY 2024)

options.label: A

options.label: B

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with testicular mass. Gross image is provided. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents to the OPD with a history of lower back pain and painful urination. On workup, it reveals normocytic normochromic anemia with hypercalcemia. Serum protein electrophoresis was done that shows M Spike in gamma region. Which of the following should be used to confirm the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.correct_answer: B. Bence Jones proteins in urine
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bence Jones proteins in urine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The detection of Bence Jones proteins in the urine is a key diagnostic test for confirming multiple myeloma, especially when the clinical presentation includes back pain, anemia, hypercalcemia, and an M spike on serum protein electrophoresis.

questions.text: A patient was admitted with complaints of tachycardia, arrhythmias. On examination, multiple scratch marks were present over the body. Probable drug of abuse in above patient is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cocaine

  • ➤ “Cocaine is the drug of abuse”

questions.text: Case fatality rate of the disease rabies is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Case fatality rate (CFR) is used to measure the virulence of organism or killing power of a disease. CFR for COVID-19 and Chickenpox is about 1%. Measles has a CFR of 3%. Rabies has the highest CFR at nearly 100%, with no cure available once symptoms appear.
  • ➤ Case fatality rate (CFR) is used to measure the virulence of organism or killing power of a disease.

  • ➤ Measles has a CFR of 3%.

questions.text: A man with diabetes was on medication and forgot to take his meals before going to the gym. During his workout, he collapsed, and his blood sugar level was found to be 50 mg/dL. Which of the following oral antidiabetic drugs can result in hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Insulin Secretagogues: Sulfonylureas, such as glimepiride, can cause hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy due to their mechanism of increasing insulin release from the pancreas.
  • ➤ Insulin
  • ➤ Secretagogues: Sulfonylureas, such as glimepiride, can cause hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy due to their mechanism of increasing insulin release from the pancreas.

questions.text: Which one of the following is correct regarding the secondary messenger? (FMGE JULY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: They act on extracellular receptors only

options.label: B
options.text: It transmits impulses from cytoplasm to nuclear receptor

options.label: D
options.text: Act both on intracellular and extracellular receptors

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mediate intracellular hormone response

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Post-partum IUCD insertion can be inserted till? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 48h

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Postpartum IUCD can be inserted within 48 hours of delivery or after six weeks postpartum . The period between 48 hours and six weeks is contraindicated for IUCD insertion.

questions.text: Name the joint formed between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Synchondrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The joint formed between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone during development is a synchondrosis, which is a primary cartilaginous joint composed of hyaline cartilage that eventually ossifies as growth completes.

questions.text: Splenectomy is contraindicated in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bone marrow failure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Splenectomy is contraindicated in bone marrow failure, as the underlying issue resides in the bone marrow's inability to produce blood cells.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with painful genital ulcers along with painful inguinal buboes. He had a history of multiple sexual partners. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chancroid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chancroid should be suspected in a patient with painful genital ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes), especially in the absence of a history of recurrence and when syphilis and LGV have been ruled out based on the clinical presentation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female has appreciable shortening in her right leg. She is diagnosed with TB Hip. Her presentation will come under which stage? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Stage III

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stage III of TB hip is characterized by late or advanced arthritis with appreciable shortening of the leg (> 1 cm).
  • ➤ Stage III of TB hip is characterized by late or advanced arthritis with appreciable shortening of the leg (> 1 cm).

questions.text: A child with a sore throat/upper respiratory tract infection (URTI) started developing skin lesions after treatment with Amoxiclav as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Guttate psoriasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: The chronic alcoholic patient had a history of strenuous exercise but forgot to take his meal, later had alcohol in a party, and presented with hypoglycemia. Which of the following processes is inhibited by alcohol? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gluconeogenesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alcohol metabolism produces excess NADH, which inhibits gluconeogenesis by depleting pyruvate and oxaloacetate, leading to hypoglycemia.

questions.text: Zellweger syndrome is due to which of the following? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Peroxisomes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zellweger syndrome is caused by a defect in peroxisomes, leading to the accumulation of very long-chain fatty acids and branched-chain fatty acids, which are not properly metabolized due to the lack of functional peroxisomes.

questions.text: Which menstrual cycle length is abnormal? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • According to the latest FIGO (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) classification, the normal menstrual cycle length ranges from 24 to 38 days. A cycle length exceeding 38 days is considered abnormal and is classified as infrequent or delayed menstruation. Previously, the normal range was considered 21 to 35 days, but this has been updated to reflect a broader range of normal cycle lengths.
  • • normal menstrual cycle length ranges from 24 to 38 days.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Menstrual cycle abnormalities are categorized based on the frequency of the cycles:
  • ➤ Frequent cycles: Less than 24 days Normal cycles: 24 to 38 days Infrequent cycles: More than 38 days
  • ➤ Frequent cycles: Less than 24 days
  • ➤ Frequent cycles:
  • ➤ Normal cycles: 24 to 38 days
  • ➤ Normal cycles:
  • ➤ Infrequent cycles: More than 38 days
  • ➤ Infrequent cycles:
  • ➤ Understanding these classifications helps in diagnosing and managing menstrual disorders effectively.

questions.text: An 85-year-old man with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with severe ear pain and discharge from his right ear. On examination, there is granulation tissue in the external auditory canal, and the patient is found to have facial nerve weakness. His HbA1c is 10%, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa is isolated from ear discharge cultures. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Malignant otitis externa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Malignant otitis externa is a severe infection of the external ear, typically caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa in elderly diabetics. It presents with severe otalgia, purulent discharge, and facial nerve involvement, requiring aggressive treatment with antibiotics and close monitoring.

questions.text: What will be the symptoms of a fracture at the marked area? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anosmia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A fracture of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone can lead to anosmia due to damage to the olfactory nerves. This area is crucial for the sense of smell.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with fever, significant weight loss, and abdominal swelling over the past two months. On physical examination, he has marked hepatosplenomegaly and pallor. He recently returned from a rural region in India. Based on his symptoms and history, visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar) is suspected. Which of the following is the most likely reservoir for the Leishmania parasite in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Human

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In India, humans are the main reservoir for kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis) , a protozoal disease transmitted by sandflies. The disease is characterized by fever, hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, and weight loss, and the diagnosis is confirmed by identifying Leishmania amastigotes in tissue samples. Treatment involves the use of amphotericin B as the first-line drug.
  • ➤ humans
  • ➤ kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis)
  • ➤ amphotericin B

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with fever, fatigue, and a new heart murmur. He has a history of poor dental hygiene and recently underwent a dental procedure. Blood cultures reveal gram-positive cocci arranged in chains, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely etiological agent responsible for his condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Streptococcus viridans is a common cause of subacute infective endocarditis, particularly in individuals with poor dental hygiene or following dental procedures. Gram-positive cocci arranged in chains on microscopy is a key finding, and early diagnosis with blood cultures and antibiotic treatment is essential for patient outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following hormone is released from zona fasciculata? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A person fell in the dark while climbing stairs and sustained an injury to the posterior triangle of the neck from an iron nail. Afterwards, he experienced difficulty in raising his shoulder and was unable to shrug. Which structure is most likely to be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Accessory nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The accessory nerve is crucial for the function of the trapezius muscle, which enables the shrugging of the shoulder. An injury to this nerve can result in the inability to perform this action.

questions.text: Sudden loss of vision without fundal glow without history of trauma is caused by: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vitreous hemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sudden loss of vision combined with absence of fundal glow, without a history of trauma, is highly characteristic of vitreous hemorrhage. This condition requires prompt evaluation to determine the underlying cause, which could include proliferative diabetic retinopathy, Eales disease, central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO), or other vascular abnormalities of the retina

questions.text: An individual experiences intense fear and anxiety when confronted with tall structures and the prospect of looking down from great heights. Which term best describes this condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
